The British Turkish fashion designer, 46, didn’t listen — and has continued to populate their London home with figures purchased from flea markets and small auction houses. These “roommates,” as Moralioglu calls them, are situated among the couple’s portrait paintings (“The dourer and more melancholic,” he says, “the better”) and contemporary photographs by Rineke Dijkstra, Nan Goldin and Candida Höfer. Many of the busts are by unknown artists and share a common aesthetic: attenuated features and graceful lines. It’s no coincidence that Moralioglu — a purveyor of romantic silhouettes made from sumptuous fabrics — begins each design sketch with a face. “The pieces that I’m attracted to have a slight illustrative quality to them,” he says. “There’s a strange correlation between the way I draw and the way some of the busts look.”

content: Bob Marley was an enigma, a fascinatingly flawed idealist as most interesting figures are. Born into poverty in Nine Mile, Jamaica, the young Marley had weak singing pipes but a stubborn drive to be heard. He forged himself into the voice of his island and beyond, belting reggae anthems that have become hymnals to the world’s downtrodden, as well as anyone who likes a good groove. He died in 1981 at the age of 36 before he had to witness his legacy undergo a tough cross-examination. Did Marley’s generosity to strangers balance out his dismissal of women? author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Thursday Briefing: Indonesia’s New Leader
description: Also, a coalition forms in Pakistan and motorbikes pile high in Vietnam.
content: Prabowo Subianto was ejected from the military in the late 1990s for his involvement in the torture and abduction of pro-democracy activists. Now, he is projected to win Indonesia’s presidency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefano Montali
title: They Set Out to Find the Truth About Love. They Found Many.
description: “Excuse me, are you two a couple?” The Times hit the streets with the team behind Meet Cutes NYC, which captures microportraits of modern love.
content: On Spring Street in Lower Manhattan, tourists slide in line for a “cronut.” A group of 20-somethings play pickleball on a court nearby. Along the sidewalk, couples stroll hand in hand, squinting in the sun on an abnormally warm winter morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: ‘Spot On’ Spaghetti Carbonara
description: Five stars, 11,000 reviews, five ingredients, 35 minutes. Valentine’s Day dinner, solved.
content: Happy Valentine’s Day to all who celebrate! I do, enthusiastically. I’ll take any excuse to bring out oysters, Champagne and chocolate on the same evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rhaina Cohen
title: The Key to a Happy, Stable Marriage
description: Couples shouldn’t be cocooned but anchored in a circle of friends.
content: When Bert Ellison experienced intense mood swings, the first person he turned to was usually not his wife but Dan Driscoll, his close friend of more than two decades. During the first year of his Ph.D. program, Mr. Ellison was an emotional yo-yo, one day telling his wife that he wanted to quit, the next that all was well. Mr. Driscoll suggested that Mr. Ellison take the concerns to him first, easing the stress on their marriage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: The Year Chatbots Were Tamed
description: A year ago, a rogue A.I. tried to break up my marriage. Did the backlash help make chatbots too boring?
content: A year ago, on Valentine’s Day, I said good night to my wife, went to my home office to answer some emails and accidentally had the strangest first date of my life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni
title: A Collapse of the Amazon Could Be Coming ‘Faster Than We Thought’
description: A new study weighed a range of threats and variables in an effort to map out where the rainforest is most vulnerable.
content: Up to half of the Amazon rainforest could transform into grasslands or weakened ecosystems in the coming decades, a new study found, as climate change, deforestation and severe droughts like the one the region is currently experiencing damage huge areas beyond their ability to recover.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: 4 Students Shot Outside Atlanta High School
description: The students were fired at from a vehicle and were taken to a hospital with non-life-threatening injuries.
content: Four students were shot in the parking lot of an Atlanta high school on Wednesday afternoon, the police said, in the latest burst of gun violence on an American school campus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: The Republican House Majority Just Became Even Smaller
description: Also, a strongman is on track to lead Indonesia. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: When the Democrat Tom Suozzi won yesterday in a special election in New York, it narrowed the Republican majority in the House to the point where the party can only afford two defections on otherwise party-line votes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Becky Ferreira
title: Mysterious Pattern in a Cave Is Oldest Rock Art Found in Patagonia
description: About 8,200 years ago, in one of the last places settled by humans, prehistoric peoples began painting comblike designs as the climate shifted.
content: In the stark inland desert of Patagonia in Argentina, there is a remote cave decorated with nearly 900 paintings of human figures, animals and abstract designs. Until recently, archaeologists had assumed that the rock art at this site, known as Cueva Huenul 1, was created within the past few thousand years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: How Protected Am I Against the Covid Variant JN.1?
description: JN.1 accounts for nearly all U.S. Covid cases. Here’s what to know about the risk of a new infection.
content: Over the last few years, the general assumption has been that a Covid infection — or vaccination — is likely to buy you a few months of protection. But any time we get a new variant that is especially adept at evading the immune system, like JN.1, that assumption gets thrown into question.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Sheriff’s Deputies Shoot Woman Inside Friend’s Home in Houston, Authorities Say
description: Body camera footage released on Saturday showed the two Harris County deputies repeatedly firing through the apartment’s window after a report of a break-in.
content: A Houston woman was shot in her friend’s apartment this month by sheriff’s deputies who responded to a report of a break-in and fired repeatedly into the home, according to a statement and body camera footage released by the Harris County Sheriff’s Office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Is Earlier Better for Theater Start Times?
description: In an effort to entice audiences back after the pandemic, Britain’s National Theater is testing a 6:30 p.m. curtain.
content: At 6:30 p.m. on a recent Thursday, most London theatergoers were still busy at work, or eating a preshow dinner, or maybe waiting at home for a babysitter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Katie Glueck
title: Leaning Into Migrant Woes, Suozzi Paves Election-Year Path for Democrats
description: Tom Suozzi’s victory in a special House election in New York buoyed Democrats’ spirits and offered a model on one of the party’s thorniest challenges: immigration.
content: In the heart of Long Island, where Republicans have won every major election in the last three years, Tom Suozzi fought through ripping political headwinds to claim victory on Tuesday in a special House election, seizing a coveted swing district that had been held by George Santos.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Editors’ Note: Feb. 14, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Feb. 14, 2024.
content: A theater review on Feb. 7 about “The Connector” included a reference to Sabrina Rubin Erdely and her reporting in Rolling Stone that lacked context. While Erdely and her editors came under scrutiny for journalistic lapses that resulted in the retraction of an article, Erdely did not invent a story or intentionally publish false information.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Curtis, Lynn Levy, Sophia Lanman and W.M.Akers
title: Presidential Love Letters Through the Ages
description: “Are You Prepared for the Storm of Love Making?” is a touching and hilarious Valentine’s Day read
content: W.M. Akers, a contributor to The New York Times Book Review, recently read a new collection of presidential love letters that delighted him. It’s called “Are You Prepared for the Storm of Love Making: Letters of Love and Lust from the White House,” by Dorothy and Thomas Hoobler. In this episode, W.M. shares a few of his favorite excerpts from Calvin Coolidge, Richard Nixon and Warren G. Harding. Some letters are sweet, some are salacious, but each provides a glimpse into the private life of a very public figure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: I.R.S. Commissioner Aims to Show Progress Amid Threats of Budget Cuts
description: Daniel Werfel will try to persuade skeptical Republicans on Thursday that funding the tax agency is a good investment.
content: At his Senate confirmation last February, Daniel Werfel told lawmakers that if given the job of Internal Revenue Service commissioner he would work to increase “public trust” in the beleaguered agency and use the $80 billion that Congress had granted it to build a “more modern and high-performing” organization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carson Griffith
title: Nothing Says Status Like a Hotel Bathrobe
description: Items like hats, T-shirts, towels and, yes, bathrobes from luxury properties have become sought-after swag, even for people who haven’t stayed at them.
content: When Marisa Coulson, her husband and daughter moved to Majorca from New York in 2019, she packed her collection of branded hotel items, including a sweatshirt from Sunset Beach Hotel on Shelter Island; a hat from the Dunmore in Harbour Island, the Bahamas; and an “ancient” sweater fraying at the seams from the Chateau Marmont, a West Hollywood hotel known for its celebrity residents and scandals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Together ‘There Was Magic’: Two Fluid Dancers in Our Racing Times
description: The nonbinary dancers Ashton Edwards and Taylor Stanley made history in their magnetic performance of Justin Peck’s “The Times Are Racing” at New York City Ballet.
content: Ashton Edwards rushed across the stage and straight into Taylor Stanley’s arms on a Sunday afternoon at New York City Ballet. This wasn’t unexpected. In “The Times Are Racing,” a fervent ballet by Justin Peck, that hug is part of the choreography — a freeze-frame of raw emotion, like a stop sign dropped into a sea of hurtling, sweeping bodies. The embrace is a signal for a new beginning: an intimate pas de deux that unfolds like a dream within a dream.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Taylor Swift Conspiracy Theory Is Embraced by Nearly 1 in 5 Americans, Poll Finds
description: Eighteen percent believe there is “a covert government effort” for the pop icon to help President Biden win re-election, according to a Monmouth University survey.
content: The Super Bowl may be over, but right-wing conspiracy theories about Taylor Swift and the 2024 presidential election are still raging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman and Patrick Kingsley
title: Israeli Minister Blocks Flour From Reaching UNRWA in Gaza
description: Israel’s finance minister, Bezalel Smotrich, said he had ordered flour shipments not to be transferred to the agency that aids Palestinians, citing allegations that some of its employees were affiliated with Hamas.
content: The Israeli finance ministry has blocked deliveries of food for Gaza because the shipments were intended to reach the main U.N. agency for Palestinians, Israel’s finance minister, Bezalel Smotrich, said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Rojas and Calla Kessler
title: The Art of Ash Wednesday, From the Neck Up
description: From smear shape to application style, a close look at the aesthetics of Ash Wednesday.
content: Mary Enright has worn her red hair in bangs as long as she’s had hair. Wednesday was no exception.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Vincler
title: Art in Multiples, Back at the Armory
description: The Print Fair returns to Park Avenue, with a critic’s advice on connoisseurship, and where the buys are.
content: Few art fairs feature Gerhard Richter rubbing shoulders with Titian. But the International Fine Print Dealers Association Print Fair, which opens on Thursday with a preview and runs through the weekend, regularly makes neighbors of the old and the new, while providing opportunities for emerging artists and emerging collectors, with some works on offer for less than $1,000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Chides Donald Trump for His Pick for the R.N.C.
description: “Oh man, poor Eric,” Jimmy Kimmel said after Trump recommended that his son’s wife, Lara, be named co-chair of the Republican National Committee.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin and Jesus Jiménez
title: At Least 1 Dead and 5 Injured After Vehicle Crashes Into Texas Hospital
description: Police were investigating what caused the crash at St. David’s North Austin Medical Center.
content: One person died and at least five people were injured, including two children, after a vehicle crashed into a hospital emergency room in Austin, Texas, on Tuesday, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: In ‘The Apiary,’ the Bees Have a Troubling Tale to Tell
description: Worldwide colony collapse is the subject of a bright, strange, upbeat thought experiment about insect hives, and our own.
content: Here’s a pitch you haven’t heard before. It’s 2046. Bees in the wild have succumbed to a planet-wide die-off, taking almonds, avocados and honey down with them. But in a subterranean lab, three women doing “palliative care” with four remaining broods make a hopeful if gruesome discovery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Seven Takeaways From the Democrats’ Recapture of a House Seat
description: George Santos, snow and old-fashioned experience were factors in the special election in New York, but none was bigger than how Tom Suozzi responded to the migrant crisis.
content: Tom Suozzi’s victory in a special House election in New York on Tuesday gave Democrats a badly needed dose of election-year optimism and a model for how to navigate one of their biggest political liabilities: the migrant influx overwhelming the southern border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: A Model for Modern ‘Ring’ Operas Is Unfolding in Brussels
description: Romeo Castellucci’s production of Wagner’s “Ring” at La Monnaie embodies ideas that the Metropolitan Opera should take note of for its own staging.
content: Before Act II of Romeo Castellucci’s new staging of Wagner’s “Die Walküre,” at La Monnaie in Brussels, a note projected onto the curtain reads: “This production respects animals and takes care of their well-being as a priority.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Pierson
title: As China Tries to Present a Friendlier Image, a New Face Emerges
description: Liu Jianchao is a Communist Party diplomat skilled at defending tough positions without being pugnacious. He also once hunted fugitive officials abroad.
content: Faced with declining foreign investment at home, China has sought to soften its image in the United States and Europe and make nice with some of its neighbors. One Communist Party official has played an unusually prominent role in the shift in tone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niela Orr
title: Tubi Is Reviving a Lost Joy: Watching Really, Really Bad Movies
description: Their films have gone viral for their awful production values. But their success says fascinating things about what comes after prestige TV.
content: There’s a 2008 movie that offers an odd preview of today’s entertainment. In Michel Gondry’s “Be Kind Rewind,” a bizarre accident demagnetizes the entire inventory of a video rental store, so a clerk and his eccentric friend decide to remake all the films themselves, from “The Lion King” to “Driving Miss Daisy” to “2001: A Space Odyssey.” Their versions are 20 minutes long (at most), shot on an old hand-held video camera and produced in a delightfully quirky, ad hoc way: handcrafted props and sets, buddies working as extras, costumes from the local dry cleaner. They call their tapes “Sweded,” explaining the time it takes to supply films by claiming the copies have to be imported from Scandinavia. In Gondry’s fantasy, the community responds well to this homespun cinema: Not only does demand go up, but store patrons begin to participate in making the movies. Gondry’s theory, he has said, was that “people would enjoy films better if they shot them themselves.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman
title: F.B.I. Director Makes a Secret Trip to Israel
description: Christopher A. Wray, whose agency has worked with Israeli authorities to pursue atrocities committed by Hamas, has made his first visit to Israel since the war began, the bureau disclosed.
content: Christopher A. Wray, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, made an unannounced trip to Israel on Wednesday to meet with officials from the country’s intelligence and law enforcement agencies, the F.B.I. said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Brooklyn Man Is Charged With Assaulting Police Officers at Jan. 6 Riot
description: Mitchell Bosch repeatedly pushed against officers as they sought to hold back the mob loyal to former President Donald J. Trump that stormed the U.S. Capitol.
content: A Brooklyn man who, along with others, physically resisted law enforcement officers’ efforts to hold back the mob that stormed the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, was charged with several crimes on Wednesday for what prosecutors said was his role in the riot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes, Karoun Demirjian, Eric Schmitt and David E. Sanger
title: Russia’s Advances on Space-Based Nuclear Weapon Draw U.S. Concerns
description: A congressman’s cryptic statement about new intelligence set Washington abuzz and infuriated White House officials.
content: The United States has informed Congress and its allies in Europe about Russian advances on a new, space-based nuclear weapon designed to threaten America’s extensive satellite network, according to current and former officials briefed on the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke
title: Review: Twyla Tharp From Three Sides Now
description: Her program at the Joyce Theater features an extroverted dance from 1975 and two new works: an introspective solo to Jacques Brel and an antic look at a choreographer creating.
content: Twyla Tharp takes making dances very seriously but, at 82, she appears to be having some fun with it — and even poking fun at herself, lightly, in the process. Her new ensemble work, “The Ballet Master,” which had its premiere on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater, depicts a choreographer immersed in the tortured and revelatory journey of bringing a work to life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Rhodes and Jacob K
title: Fashion Has Entered a New Era of Elegance
description: Sixties-inspired shapes and glossy finishes mark a return to polish and playfulness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: How Senate Democrats Flipped the Border Issue on Republicans
description: Senator Chuck Schumer was wary of tying immigration policy to emergency aid for Ukraine, but he saw an opening to address border turmoil that was becoming a political liability — and to call Republicans’ bluff.
content: As senators gathered on the floor for a typical Monday night vote at the end of October, Senator Mitch McConnell, the Kentucky Republican and minority leader, approached Senator Chuck Schumer, his Democratic counterpart, with some unsettling news: Border security was going to have to be part of any package to free up endangered assistance for Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Some Pregnant Women and Infants Received the Wrong R.S.V. Shots
description: Doctors and pharmacists seem to be confused by the guidelines. And the brand names aren’t helping.
content: This winter, for the first time ever, there were two vaccines available to ward off respiratory syncytial virus, which is particularly dangerous to older adults and infants. Only one of them — Abrysvo, made by Pfizer — was approved for pregnant women, and neither was for young children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Rosenwald
title: Joel Belz, Trailblazer in Christian Journalism, Is Dead at 82
description: Inspired by Time, he founded World magazine, covering politics, the arts and other subjects from a “God’s-eye” view.
content: Joel Belz, the founder of World, a pioneering Christian magazine covering politics, culture and other topics through a biblical lens while occasionally drawing wider notice for its reporting on prominent religious figures behaving less than holy, died on Feb. 4 at his home in Asheville, N.C. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: Three Lessons From a Surprisingly Resilient Job Market
description: The recovery from the pandemic lockdowns has prompted economists to consider whether their playbook is outdated or just missing a page.
content: The pandemic created an economic crisis unlike any recession on record. So perhaps it shouldn’t be surprising that the aftermath, too, has played out in a way that almost no economists expected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Jared Kushner Passes on Idea of Joining a Second Trump Administration
description: Mr. Kushner was an influential senior adviser to Donald J. Trump, his father-in-law, during Mr. Trump’s term in the White House.
content: Jared Kushner ruled out on Tuesday a return to the White House if his father-in-law, former President Donald J. Trump, were elected in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naveen Kumar
title: ‘Between Two Knees’ Review: A Virtuosic Romp Through a Century of Terrors
description: Two deadly standoffs at Wounded Knee are the bookends for a show that manages to narrate a violent history with moments of light and humor.
content: Rapid-fire punchlines and crafty sight gags may not seem the most obvious means to convey a brutal history of displacement and extermination. But “Between Two Knees,” which opened at the Perelman Performing Arts Center in Manhattan on Tuesday, uses both in an audaciously sidesplitting comedy that’s an indictment of Native American persecution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: How to Give Your Photos and Videos a Vintage Look
description: Retro-photography apps that mimic the appearance of analog film formats make your digital files seem like they’re from another era.
content: Like the allure of vinyl records, classic video games and even the early internet, the fascination with older photography standards like point-and-shoot cameras or 35-millimeter film persists — even in people too young to remember when that gear was cutting edge. The appeal of “vintage” photography goes beyond nostalgia and Instagram filters, judging by the huge number of apps designed to emulate the film, lenses and visual quirks of predigital photos and movies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: What the Dutch Lost When They Lost Manhattan
description: Nutmeg is lovely, but it can’t support a robust economy.
content: Last week The Times ran a wonderful article about Pulau Rhun, a tiny, nutmeg-growing island in what is now Indonesia that Britain traded for Manhattan — sort of — in 1667. Considering the diverging fortunes of the two islands since that year, this appears at first blush to be the worst deal in history for the Dutch, who formally gained Rhun and lost Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: Macron Says Booksellers Can Stay Put During Olympic Games
description: The French president’s decision brought relief to the sellers who have long operated near the Seine, and avoided a standoff.
content: Gold-leafed books with engravings, 200-year-old leather-bound books, books so rare and precious they are wrapped carefully in cellophane before being nestled into place inside an antique wooden box set on the Seine’s stony shoulder for students, intellectuals, power brokers and tourists to browse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz, Isayen Herrera and Genevieve Glatsky
title: In Venezuela, You’re a Critic One Day, and Arrested the Next
description: The detention of Rocío San Miguel, and her disappearance for many days, has Venezuelan human right activists concerned that they have entered a new era of repression.
content: Of all the government critics, few thought that Rocío San Miguel would be the one to disappear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: Indonesia’s Vote: Three Takeaways for Climate Change
description: The presumed winner supports policies that have led to a boom in coal-burning, but also to the creation of a nascent electric-battery industry.

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Austin, Speaking by Video, Reiterates U.S. Support for Ukraine
description: Secretary of Defense Lloyd J. Austin III spoke on Wednesday to a U.S.-led group that marshals military aid to Ukraine.
content: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III, speaking by video, told defense ministers meeting in Brussels Wednesday that the United States would maintain its support for Ukraine, but he made no mention of a multibillion-dollar aid package that has yet to gain Congressional approval.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: The U.K. Labour Party’s Worst Enemy Might Be Itself
description: The party has a large lead in the polls but recent missteps have led to questions about the management skills of its leader, Keir Starmer.
content: These days, the only thing that can stop the Labour Party, it seems, is the Labour Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: Locust Swarms Could Expand Their Range in a Hotter, Stormier World
description: The crop-devouring pests love arid conditions and the occasional downpour. Global warming is offering more of both.
content: Rising temperatures could expand the area of the globe under threat from crop-devouring locusts by up to 25 percent in the coming decades, a new study found, as more places experience the cycles of drought and torrential rain that give rise to biblical swarms of the insects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: House Republican Majority Shrinks Again as Congress Faces Critical Issues
description: The victory of Tom Suozzi, a Democrat, in a special election in New York will chip away at the already thin Republican hold over the House.
content: And then there were two.

author: By Alex Vadukul and Jutharat Pinyodoonyachet
title: Cast of ‘The New Look’ Reflects on Chanel and Dior’s War-Torn Past
description: Juliette Binoche, Ben Mendelsohn and John Malkovich, stars of a new series set in World War II Paris, discussed French fashion history at the show’s premiere in New York.
content: On Monday evening along Madison Avenue in Manhattan, while fashionistas on the Upper East Side finished their shopping rounds at Dior and Chanel, a crowd headed to the French Institute Alliance Française to attend the premiere of an Apple TV+ series that recounts the origin story of those two fashion houses through the tale of Coco Chanel and Christian Dior’s lives in war-torn Paris during the 1940s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Not an Ordinary Special Election, and Yet a Typical Result
description: Democrats claim another victory, although it doesn’t necessarily add more clarity about November.
content: As I prepared to write this ahead of Tuesday’s special election to replace George Santos in New York’s Third District, two completely different outcomes seemed easy to imagine — or explain away.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Rethinking the Prospects of a ‘Soft Landing’
description: Worries of higher-for-longer interest rates have grown since Tuesday’s Consumer Price Index report.
content: Markets are still on edge after Tuesday’s hot inflation report, as Wall Street suddenly and sharply discounted the odds of imminent interest rate cuts.

description: Ms. OConnell, a longtime executive at Disney, will become the president of a newly created division that will include ABC News and the company’s local stations.
content: The Walt Disney Company announced on Wednesday that a longtime executive at the company, Debra OConnell, would become the president of a newly created division that will include ABC News and the company’s local stations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Wilhelmenia Wiggins Fernandez, the Diva of ‘Diva,’ Dies at 75
description: A soprano who rose from South Philadelphia to the opera houses of Europe, she was memorably seen and heard in a 1981 film considered a paragon of cinematic style.
content: Wilhelmenia Wiggins Fernandez, a South Philadelphia-bred soprano who sang in the opera houses of Europe and gained even more fame for playing the title role in the style-soaked 1981 French thriller “Diva,” died on Feb. 2 at her home in Lexington, Ky. She was 75.

author: By Hamed Aleaziz and Miriam Jordan
title: Illegal Border Crossings Plummeted in January
description: The report is good news for President Biden, but doesn’t change the fact that the number of people crossing into the U.S. has reached record levels during his term.
content: The number of people crossing illegally into the United States from Mexico has dropped by 50 percent in the past month, authorities said on Tuesday, as President Biden comes under growing pressure from both parties over security at the border.

title: A Feared Ex-General Appears Set to Become Indonesia’s New Leader
description: Prabowo Subianto was ejected from the military on accusations of rights abuses. Now, he is projected to win the country’s presidency outright in the first round.
content: Indonesia’s defense minister, a feared former general who was removed from the army after he was found responsible for the kidnapping of political dissidents, appeared to be on track to win the presidential election outright on Wednesday, casting doubts on the future of one of the world’s most vibrant democracies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Bleeding Love’ Review: On the Road With Dad
description: Ewan McGregor plays father to his real-life daughter Clara McGregor in this indie road-trip movie that’s also a meandering journey to healing.
content: This week’s Valentine blues arrive courtesy of “Bleeding Love,” a father-daughter story about love, lies and family trauma starring a real father-daughter duo. The dramatic duet opens with the nameless father (Ewan McGregor) already behind the wheel of his pickup truck with his nameless, angrily sullen daughter (Clara McGregor) riding shotgun. They’re on a highway headed toward Santa Fe, N.M., though it soon becomes evident that they’re also on the road to reconciliation — that byway many indie-film families travel in order to heal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By María Sánchez Díez
title: Lucy Sante Is the Same Writer She Has Always Been
description: In her memoir “I Heard Her Call My Name,” the author reflects on her life and embarking on a gender transition in her late 60s.
content: It took a lifetime.

author: By Showkat Nanda
title: Braving the Winter to Visit a Valley Shrouded in Snow and Secrets
description: Compelled by stories he’d heard as a child, the photographer Showkat Nanda traveled to the high Himalayas to see Gurez, a valley long off-limits to most travelers.
content: As the chopper rose into the sky, my heart raced with excitement and a twinge of fear: This was my first helicopter ride. The man beside me glanced over and asked why I’d choose to visit the Gurez Valley now, when it had so little to offer. “Even the locals avoid it if they can,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Why Farmers Are Marching Toward Delhi Again
description: This time they want a stronger guarantee that they can make money selling their wheat and rice crops.
content: Once again, India’s capital is bracing itself for a siege. Not by a foreign army but by an army of Indian farmers, streaming toward New Delhi from nearby states to protest government policies.

title: Israel Media Report Netanyahu Has Pulled Out of Cease-fire Talks in Egypt
description: Some family members of the hostages still in Gaza criticized any such decision and protested outside the homes of Israeli officials.
content: As talks continued in Cairo toward an Israel-Hamas cease-fire, Israeli media reported on Wednesday that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu had told his negotiators not to take part, infuriating some family members of hostages still in Gaza who say that the government is not doing enough to rescue their relatives.

title: Angela Chao, C.E.O. of Family’s Big Shipping Company, Dies at 50
description: Ms. Chao, whose sister Elaine Chao was President Trump’s secretary of transportation, led Foremost Group, operator of a global fleet of carrier ships. She died in a car crash.
content: Angela Chao, the chief executive of a shipping company and part of a family prominent in American politics and business deals with China, died in a car crash on Sunday, in Texas. She was 50.

author: By Kenneth F. McKenzie Jr
title: It’s Not Time for Our Troops to Leave the Middle East
description: Should U.S. troops stay in Syria and Iraq, or should they go? And if they stay, how does American leadership prevent these attacks from continuing?
content: The United States base at Tower 22 in Jordan is in the middle of a seemingly unending desert, astride the ancient Damascus-Baghdad Highway near the border with Syria. In January it is cold, often rainy and very bleak. Last month three U.S. service members at Tower 22 were killed by a drone launched by an Iranian-backed militia. Their deaths prompted more than 80 retaliatory strikes by the United States against the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps and militias operating in Iraq and Syria.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays and Mihir Zaveri
title: Mayor Adams Is Sued Over Failure to Comply With New Housing Laws
description: The City Council is expected to join the Legal Aid Society in a lawsuit to force Mr. Adams to implement laws aimed at reducing homelessness.
content: The Legal Aid Society sued Mayor Eric Adams on Wednesday for not complying with new laws meant to address rising homelessness and the influx of tens of thousands of migrants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: A Greek Refugee Camp Went Up in Flames. The Aftermath Was Even Worse.
description: A devastating 2020 fire on the island of Lesbos is the springboard for a meditation on origin stories, borders and migration in Lauren Markham’s “A Map of Future Ruins.”
content: More than three years after the fact, we still know too little about what happened in the migrant camp known as Moria, on the Greek island of Lesbos, on Sept. 8, 2020. That night, a fire started in Moria’s Zone 6, one of the makeshift areas abutting the main camp’s walls. Flames tore through the tents, the embers carried by the wind, leaving most of Moria’s 11,000 residents homeless.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: An English City Gave Soccer to the World. Now It Wants Credit.
description: Sheffield says it was home to the planet’s first real soccer culture. Staking a claim to that honor may hold the key to its future.
content: As far as the man in the food truck is concerned, the patch of land he occupies in Sheffield, England, is about as humdrum as they come. To him, the spot — in the drab parking lot of a sprawling home improvement superstore, its facade plastered in lurid orange — is not exactly a place where history comes alive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Shell Sees Demand Surging for Liquefied Natural Gas
description: Asia will be the dominant consumer, while the U.S. will be the key supplier. In Europe, where L.N.G. has been a lifeline, the need will continue despite environmental concerns.
content: Shell, Europe’s largest energy company, forecast on Wednesday that global demand for liquefied natural gas, which has been a lifeline for Europe after Russia cut off pipeline gas supplies, will surge by around 50 percent over the next 15 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova and Marc Santora
title: Ukraine, Struggling on Land, Claims to Deal Blow to Russia at Sea
description: The Ukrainian military says it has sunk a large Russian landing ship off the coast of Crimea, although Ukrainian troops inland find themselves in a precarious position.
content: Ukraine said on Wednesday that its forces had sunk a large Russian ship off the coast of Crimea before dawn, in what would be another powerful blow against the Russians at sea, as outgunned Ukrainian soldiers struggle to hold back bloody assaults on land.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Haley Trails Trump by 36 Points in South Carolina, New Poll Shows
description: Nearly two-thirds of likely voters, 65 percent, said in a Winthrop University poll that they supported former President Donald J. Trump, and only 29 percent supported Nikki Haley.
content: A Winthrop University poll released Wednesday shows Nikki Haley losing badly in South Carolina, her home state, with a little more than a week before the state’s Republican primary.

content: I’m a member of Gen Z, and the question of who should pay for dates was never one I really stopped to think about. That changed last fall after I went out with a woman I met on Hinge, a dating app.

title: Imran Khan’s Opponents Reach Deal to Shut His Allies Out of Government
description: After days of wrangling, two parties run by political dynasties joined forces and will nominate Shehbaz Sharif to be Pakistan’s prime minister.
content: Pakistan’s two main political dynasties reached an agreement late on Tuesday to form a coalition government, ensuring that candidates aligned with former Prime Minister Imran Khan will not take power despite having won the most seats in last week’s election.

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Madame Web’ Review: Dakota Johnson Can’t Save This Spidey Spinoff
description: The actress stars as a clairvoyant in the latest entry to the Spider-Man franchise, using her charm to rise above this flat, predictable movie.
content: The only real bummer about “Madame Web,” the latest installment in the Spider-Man chronicles, isn’t that it’s bad, but that it never achieves memorably terrible status. The story is absurd, the dialogue snort-out-loud risible, the fights uninspired. Even so, there are glimmers of wit and competency. And then there’s its star, Dakota Johnson, who has a fascinating, seemingly natural ability to appear wholly detached from the nonsense swirling around her. Most actors at least try to sell the shoddy goods; Johnson serenely floats above it all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Liberal Group Joins Efforts Calling for Protest Vote Against Biden in Michigan
description: Our Revolution, begun by Senator Bernie Sanders in 2016, is aiming to shift the president’s stance on the war in Gaza.
content: Our Revolution, the political organization that Senator Bernie Sanders launched in 2016, is throwing its weight behind the movement to vote Uncommitted in Michigan’s Democratic primary, seeking to pressure President Biden into changing his approach to the war between Israel and Hamas.

title: Grover Is Now a Reporter. Journalists Aren’t Optimistic.

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Why So Many Kids Are Priced Out of Youth Sports
description: Play should be for everyone.
content: Ever since my 2022 interview with Linda Flanagan, the author of “Take Back the Game,” about how money is ruining youth sports, lots of parents have come to me with their complaints on the topic. I hear most frequently from readers and friends about the expense and time-suck of travel sports. I can’t open a social media app without seeing posts joking that you might need a mortgage broker to pay for a tech suit for swim meets, or about how “having kids involved in sports is fun, if you like coming home & eating dinner at 10 p.m.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: Should I Keep Trying to Pay a $700 Bill? I Think They Forgot to Charge Me.
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the duty one has to rectify an unpaid bill.
content: I recently rented a car from a well-known car-rental company in a tiny office connected to an Amtrak station. Renting the car at this little outpost allowed my partner and me to have a wonderful vacation visiting a national park. The staff at this small office was very helpful — the car was waiting for us when we got off the train at 10 p.m. We used it for a week and returned it on time, clean and filled with gas.

title: Mayorkas Was Impeached. What Happens Next?
description: The first impeachment of a sitting cabinet member sets off a series of choreographed rituals that dates back to the impeachment of former President Andrew Johnson in 1868.
content: Republican members of the House impeached Alejandro N. Mayorkas, the homeland security secretary, with a simple majority vote on Tuesday. It sets off a series of choreographed rituals that dates back to the impeachment of former President Andrew Johnson in 1868. Here’s a look at what happens next.

title: In New York Win, Democrats Sense a Pivot on Immigration and Border Politics
description: Tom Suozzi’s victory, coming after congressional Republicans killed a bipartisan border security package, could provide Democrats with a road map to shoring up two political vulnerabilities.
content: A victory in a New York special election on Tuesday injected Democrats with fresh optimism that the party might have found some of the basic ingredients to neutralize immigration and the border as political issues, which party officials have privately seen as among their deepest areas of vulnerability in 2024.

author: By Rob Tannenbaum
title: How ‘The Greatest Night in Pop’ Got the ’80s Right
description: The Netflix documentary revels in nostalgia. But the heart of the film spotlights the relationships between the pop superstars who recorded “We Are the World.”
content: The title of Netflix’s new documentary “The Greatest Night in Pop,” which chronicles the recording of “We Are the World,” is a little mystifying. Pop music needs a big audience, but what happened inside A&M Studios in Los Angeles, in the vampire hours between 10 p.m. on Jan. 28, 1985, and 8 a.m. the next day, was seen by only 60 to 70 people in attendance, from Michael Jackson to a small film crew. The song that resulted in this frantic, logistically improbable session is stirring but callow, with a gospel-style chord progression that gives false weight to the platitudinous lyrics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: My Oldest Friend Is Being Paroled From Prison. Can I Dump Her?
description: After supporting an old friend through years of incarceration with letters and shipments of books, a reader wants out, put off by the woman’s lies about her situation.
content: My oldest friend — we met in nursery school and are now in our 60s — is about to be paroled from prison after six years. She pleaded guilty to manslaughter in the death of her sister and to charges of animal cruelty. (Two dogs were also killed.) When she is released, she will have to move in with her parents, not far from me. She still insists that the reports of the police investigation are “all lies.” But it’s clear to me that much of what was reported was true. While she was incarcerated, I wrote her letters and sent her books because I felt sorry for her situation. But now that she is being paroled, I can’t abide the pressure to accept her lies. Any advice on exiting this relationship without causing pain?
source.name: The New York Times
